skill.name: doc-coauthoring
skill.description: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to write documentation, proposals, technical specs, decision docs, or similar structured content. This workflow helps users efficiently transfer context, refine content through iteration, and verify the doc works for readers. Trigger when user mentions writing docs, creating proposals, drafting specs, or similar documentation tasks.
skill.summary: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to wri...

security_audit.summary: OFFICIAL skill from Anthropic with no code execution, external API calls, or suspicious patterns. Pure workflow guidance using markdown instructions only.

content.value_statement: A guided three-stage process that helps you create clear, effective documentation by gathering context, refining structure iteratively, and testing with a fresh AI perspective to catch blind spots before sharing with readers.
actual_capabilities: Guides through structured three-stage documentation workflow: Context Gathering, Refinement & Structure, and Reader Testing
Asks targeted clarifying questions to close knowledge gaps between user and AI
Supports integration with Slack, Teams, Google Drive, and SharePoint to pull in context
Brainstorms 5-20 options per section and curates based on user feedback
Creates document scaffolds using artifacts or markdown files with section placeholders
Performs iterative refinement using surgical edits (str_replace) rather than full rewrites
Tests completed documents with fresh AI instances to identify reader comprehension issues
Handles multiple document types: PRDs, design docs, decision docs, RFCs, technical specs, proposals
Generates alt-text for images in shared documents to improve AI accessibility
Provides section-by-section workflow starting with sections having most unknowns
limitations: Requires user participation and feedback throughout the process - cannot autonomously complete documents
Reader testing with sub-agents only available in Claude Code environment; manual testing required in web interface
Integration features (Slack, Google Drive, etc.) depend on user having enabled MCP connectors
Process is intentionally time-intensive and may not suit users needing quick drafts
Cannot directly edit shared documents - only provides content and guidance
Assumes user has sufficient domain knowledge to provide initial context
Workflow is optimized for substantial documents, may be overkill for simple one-pagers

use_cases.title: Technical Design Document
use_cases.description: Create a comprehensive technical design doc by gathering architecture context, brainstorming implementation approaches, refining technical details section-by-section, and testing that other developers can understand the proposal without additional context.
use_cases.target_user: Software engineers, technical leads, and architects writing design specifications

use_cases.title: Product Requirements Document (PRD)
use_cases.description: Draft a PRD by collecting product context from team discussions and stakeholder feedback, structuring requirements and use cases, and validating that the document clearly communicates the product vision to engineering and design teams.
use_cases.target_user: Product managers defining features and requirements

use_cases.title: Decision Documentation (RFC)
use_cases.description: Document important technical or organizational decisions by capturing the problem context, brainstorming options and trade-offs, structuring the rationale, and ensuring future team members can understand why decisions were made.
use_cases.target_user: Team leads, architects, and managers making consequential decisions

use_cases.title: Project Proposal
use_cases.description: Build a compelling project proposal by gathering organizational context and constraints, iteratively refining the value proposition and implementation plan, and testing that stakeholders can understand the proposal's impact without prior knowledge.
use_cases.target_user: Project managers, team leads, and individual contributors pitching new initiatives

prompt_templates.title: Start New Documentation Project
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to write a [technical spec/PRD/decision doc/proposal] for [project name/topic]. Can you guide me through the doc co-authoring workflow?
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginning a new documentation task with structured guidance

prompt_templates.title: Convert Context to Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a bunch of context from #[slack-channel] and [shared doc links] about [topic]. Help me turn this into a [document type] using the structured workflow.
prompt_templates.scenario: Transforming scattered information into organized documentation

prompt_templates.title: Refine Existing Document
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a draft [document type] at [link/path]. Can you help me refine it section by section and test it with Reader Claude?
prompt_templates.scenario: Improving an existing document that needs clarity and reader validation

prompt_templates.title: Decision Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: We need to document our decision to [technical/organizational decision]. Walk me through creating a decision doc that explains the rationale and trade-offs.
prompt_templates.scenario: Capturing important decisions for future reference

output_examples.input: I need to write a technical spec for migrating our auth system to OAuth2
output_examples.output: The skill guides the user through: (1) Context gathering with questions about current auth implementation, stakeholder concerns, timeline constraints, and alternatives considered; (2) Section-by-section refinement starting with the migration approach, brainstorming 15+ considerations like backwards compatibility, token storage, session handling; (3) Testing the final spec with a fresh Claude instance asking 'What authentication pattern is being proposed?' and 'What are the migration risks?' to ensure clarity.

output_examples.input: Create a PRD for our new analytics dashboard feature
output_examples.output: The workflow starts by asking about target users, desired impact, existing analytics tools, and constraints. After the context dump, Claude asks clarifying questions about metrics prioritization and user workflows. Then builds the PRD section-by-section: brainstorming 10+ user stories for the 'Use Cases' section, curating based on feedback, drafting, and iteratively refining. Finally tests by asking a fresh Claude 'Who is this feature for?' and 'What problem does it solve?' to validate clarity.

best_practices: Accept the structured workflow when offered - it catches blind spots that freeform writing often misses
Provide context in whatever format is easiest: stream-of-consciousness dumps, channel links, or shared doc URLs
Use shorthand when answering questions (e.g., '1: yes, 2: see #channel, 3: no because backwards compat') to save time
Start with sections having the most unknowns (usually core proposal/decision) rather than introductions
Indicate what to change rather than editing the document directly - this helps Claude learn your style for future sections
Enable MCP connectors (Slack, Google Drive, etc.) before starting to allow direct context pulling
Be specific about what to keep/remove/combine when curating brainstormed options
Complete Reader Testing even if the doc seems done - it frequently catches clarity issues authors miss
Request alt-text generation for images in shared documents to ensure AI accessibility
Link the conversation in an appendix so readers can see development context if needed
anti_patterns: Skipping Context Gathering stage - leads to generic content that doesn't address specific organizational needs
Editing the document directly instead of telling Claude what to change - prevents style learning across sections
Starting with summary/introduction sections - these are better written last when core content is finalized
Accepting 'good enough' during refinement without asking if anything can be removed - leads to bloated docs
Skipping Reader Testing - authors often overestimate how clear their writing is to fresh readers
Providing only high-level feedback like 'looks good' - specific feedback improves later sections
Rushing through brainstorming by selecting everything - curation is where quality emerges
Working freeform when the document is substantial - structured workflow ensures completeness and reader clarity

faq.question: How long does this workflow typically take?
faq.answer: The workflow is intentionally thorough and time-intensive. A substantial technical spec or PRD might take 1-3 hours depending on complexity and available context. The time investment pays off by producing documentation that readers can actually understand without asking clarifying questions.

faq.question: Can I use this for short documents like one-pagers?
faq.answer: While you can use this workflow for any document, it's optimized for substantial documentation like technical specs, PRDs, and decision docs. For simple one-pagers, freeform writing might be more efficient.

faq.question: What if I don't have access to Slack/Google Drive integrations?
faq.answer: The workflow still works - you'll just paste context directly instead of Claude pulling it automatically. You can enable MCP connectors in Claude settings to add these integrations.

faq.question: How does Reader Testing work without sub-agents?
faq.answer: In environments without sub-agent access (like claude.ai web), you manually test by opening a fresh Claude conversation, pasting the document, and asking the generated questions to see if Reader Claude understands correctly.

faq.question: Can I skip stages if I'm in a hurry?
faq.answer: Yes - Claude will offer to let you work freeform if you want to skip stages. However, each stage serves a purpose: Context Gathering prevents generic content, Refinement ensures quality, and Reader Testing catches blind spots that waste readers' time later.

faq.question: What document types work best with this workflow?
faq.answer: PRDs, technical specs, design docs, decision docs (RFCs), project proposals, and any substantial documentation meant to be read and understood by others without additional context.

faq.question: Why use artifacts or files instead of just conversational output?
faq.answer: Having a persistent document scaffold allows both you and Claude to reference and edit specific sections surgically (using str_replace) rather than rewriting entire documents. This preserves context and enables precise refinements.

faq.question: What if Reader Claude passes but real readers still have questions?
faq.answer: Reader Testing catches common comprehension issues but isn't perfect. Real reader feedback is valuable - update the document based on actual questions received and consider those patterns for future docs.
